Ideogram (æŒ‡äº‹): It is derived from a pictogram of a carriage seen from above. In the oracle bone script, there were large wheels on both sides and a sun shade on the top. Later, when Chinese characters were written vertically, the wheels on both sides were simply drawn in strokes and the loading area was marked with a ç”° (OC *l'iËÅ‹). Therefore, it is important to understand that the current character, è»Š (OC *kÊ°lja, *kla) is a vertical depiction of a carriage. Note that å€ (OC *kaËns) (as in left part of æœ (OC *Ê”r'ew, *r'ew)) is not derived from è»Š (OC *kÊ°lja, *kla).

Alternatively, it could be a pictogram (è±¡å½¢) of a person holding onto a cliff â€“ original character of æŒ¯ (OC *tjÉ¯n, *tjÉ¯ns, â€œto hold upâ€) (Shang, 1983).

Pictogram (è±¡å½¢):Â Â é¦–Â +Â Â å© â€“ head of a kneeling person, emphasising â€œheadâ€. é  and é¦– (OC *hljuÊ”, *hljus) were originally the same pictographic character with the same meaning of â€œheadâ€, and the graphical difference was that é  also included the body in addition to the head of the person. é  was later used as an alternative popular form of è‘‰ (â€œleaf; pageâ€) to mean â€œsheet; page (of paper)â€, which is its main meaning today. The original sense of â€œheadâ€ is preserved in the radical é , which is used in characters such as é ­ (â€œheadâ€) and é ¸ (â€œneckâ€).

Phono-semantic compoundÂ (å½¢è², OC *plum, *plums):Â phoneticÂ å‡¡ (OC *bom)Â +Â semanticÂ è™« (â€œinsectsâ€). Ancient Chinese thought insects appear with wind. (Insects refer to any kind of animal, such as tigers (å¤§èŸ²)). In the oracle bone script, the character é³³ (OC *bums, â€œmale fenghuangâ€) was phonetically borrowed to represent é¢¨ (OC *plum, *plums). The right part of the bronze inscription of the character consists of phonetic å‡¡ (OC *bom) at the top, and three parts depicting the fur on the tail of the male fenghuang at the bottom. Subsequent forms of é¢¨ are based on the right part of its bronze inscription, with two of the three threads of "fur" removed for simplification. The è™« in the Chu script and Qin script of é¢¨ was likely a result of further simplification of the "fur". Shuowen misinterpreted the character é¢¨ by associating it with insects. (Li, 2012)

According to Shuowen, it is both a phono-semantic compoundÂ (å½¢è², OC *É¡Ê·aËÅ‹)Â and ideogrammic compoundÂ (æœƒæ„):Â phoneticÂ ç‚— (â€œlightâ€)Â +Â semanticÂ ç”° (â€œfieldâ€) â€“ the color of earth, with ç‚— being the ancient form of å…‰ (OC *kÊ·aËÅ‹, *kÊ·aËÅ‹s, â€œlightâ€). However, this interpretation is likely erroneous as å»¿ at the top was formed as a result of corruption of å£ in the bronze inscription.  Chi (2010) proposes that é»ƒ was originally a pictogram (è±¡å½¢) and the original character of å°ª (OC *qÊ·aËÅ‹, â€œa disabled person with a protruding chest or abdomenâ€). It has been phonetically borrowed for "yellow" since the era of the oracle bone script. He (1998) noted the possible ritual of burning disabled people with a protruding chest or abdomen to pray for rain as mentioned in Zuozhuan. The å£ in the upper part of the bronze inscription of é»ƒ might be depicting the disabled person's face facing upwards. Li (2012), on the other hand, proposes that é»ƒ was originally a pictogram (è±¡å½¢) and the original character of ç’œ (OC *É¡Ê·aËÅ‹, â€œsemicircular jadeâ€) as the å£ in the oracle bone script resembles a ring of jade, so the character would carry the meaning of "a man wearing a ring of jade on his chest".
